I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  for  the  additional  financing  of  the 
Smallholder Development Project (overall project).1 

2. 
The agriculture and forestry sectors remain Lao PDR’s primary source of livelihood and 
play  a  key  role  in  reducing  national  poverty.  The  Smallholder  Development  Project  (current 
project)  has  therefore  been  promoting  sustainable  commercial  smallholder  agriculture  and 
associated  agribusiness  through  strengthening  extension  services,  enhancing  access  to 
information  and  markets,  capacity  building,  and  increasing  investments  in  agribusiness.  The 
proposed  additional  financing,  which  will  consolidate  and  expand  well-performing  investments 
initiated under the current project, covers eight new districts in the existing four provinces. 

A. 

Rationale 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

3. 
Agriculture  is  the  dominant  sector  in  Lao  PDR,  accounting  for  about  40%  of  gross 
domestic product (GDP) and more than 70% of employment. More than 85% of the population 
lives in rural areas, making a living largely by subsistence cultivation of rice. At the end of 2010, 
more than 30% of the rural population was living in poverty. The incidence of poverty, which is 
closely  linked  to  agricultural  performance,  can  be  reduced  by  moving  farmers  beyond 
subsistence  farming  to  more  diversified  and  commercial  agricultural  production  of  cash  crops 
with  ready  markets  in  neighboring  countries.  The  irrigated  floodplain  of  the  Mekong  River 
produces  most  of  the  country’s  marketable  surplus  of  rice  and  other  crops,  and  offers  the 
strongest  potential  for  commercialization  of  agriculture.  However,  even  in  these  areas,  rice 
productivity is below that of its neighbors. The productivity and quality of crops other than rice 
also remain low because of limited information on markets, poor technical expertise, restricted 
access to markets for inputs and products, lack of credit, low domestic demand, and a dearth of 
value-adding  enterprises.  The  extension  system  has  been  largely  dysfunctional  because  of 
severe  budget  constraints,  poor  organization  and  staffing,  and  a  policy  environment  not 
conducive to the efficient functioning of input and product markets. By providing simple inputs, a 
large  impact  can  be  achieved,  mainly  through  training,  awareness  raising,  and  application  of 
appropriate policies.   

Against  this  backdrop,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  the  Smallholder 
4. 
Development Project for $12 million equivalent from its Special Funds resources in November 
2002.2 The completion date was 30  June 2011 and the closing date 31 December 2011.3 The 
purpose  of  the  current  project  was  to  establish  sustainable  smallholder  agribusiness.  The 
current  project  focused  on  (i) effective  agricultural  extension  and  training  mechanisms,  (ii) 
improved physical infrastructure and marketing  of agricultural goods, and (iii) effective primary 
market networks. The current project has (i) established 162 farmer production and marketing 
groups (FPMGs) and organized training on agricultural production techniques and post-harvest

practices;  (ii)  developed  agricultural  extension  services  to  assist  farmers’  groups,  processors, 
and traders with the establishment of contract farming; (iii) upgraded 89.5 kilometers of access 
roads and built 70.8 kilometers of new feeder roads; (iv) delivered an agriculture and marketing 
information system; (v) constructed six markets; and (vi) provided post-harvest technology and 
associated equipment. These investments created a favorable environment for the development 
of  commercial  agribusiness  and  contributed  to  the  improvement  of  farmers’  incomes.  As  a 
result,  the  outcomes  of  the  Project  have  largely  been  achieved.  An  average  beneficiary 
smallholder household income in Khammouan  province, poorest among the project provinces, 
increased to $675 in 2010 from $280 in 2002.4 The same trend has been observed in the other 
project provinces.5 

5. 
As of 30 June 2011, overall physical progress was estimated at 99% against an elapsed 
loan  period  of  98%.  Total  cumulative  contract  awards  were  $12.8  million  (92%)  and 
disbursements  were  $13.1  million  (94%).  The  rate  of  disbursements  and  contract  awards 
improved significantly after the midterm review. No major issues were identified and applicable 
safeguard policies have been observed. Since the midterm review, the Project has been rated 
‘satisfactory’ in the project performance rating. Therefore, the current project is considered to be 
performing well as stipulated in the Operations Manual Section H5/OP.6 

6. 
The current project has been successful in achieving the overall development objectives 
and  demonstrated  that  (i)  capacity  building  of  farmers’  groups  is  vital  to  produce  surplus  for 
agricultural commercialization; (ii) knowledge transfer and exchange visits stimulate new ideas 
among FPMGs and encourages adoption of new agricultural techniques, and (iii) strengthening 
linkages amongst all members along the marketing chain promotes greater appreciation of their 
respective issues. Further, a number of public–private partnerships (PPPs) were initiated. These 
include (i) collaboration between rice miller groups in the rice value chain and FPMGs, (ii) the 
involvement  of  trading  groups  in  contract  farming  arrangements  and  in  providing  extension 
services and agriculture inputs to FPMGs, and (iii) cooperation with the Lao PDR–India training 
center to train farmer groups and officials on entrepreneurship and marketing. 

7. 
During  the  loan  review  mission  conducted  by  ADB  Lao  PDR  Resident  Mission  in 
February  2011,  the  government  requested  ADB  for  additional  financing  to  strengthen 
sustainable  smallholder  commercial  agriculture  by  consolidating  and  expanding  the  activities

sound;  (ii)  the  government  accords  the  Project  high  priority  through  its  request  for  additional 
financing; (iii) while project outputs will be expanded to reach more beneficiaries, the Project will 
retain the same overall objectives; and (iv) the outcome is consistent with the current  country 
partnership strategy (CPS)10 which promotes agriculture and rural development in the context of 
sustainable economic growth and improved livelihoods of vulnerable groups. 

9. 
The  Project  has  a  substantial  degree  of  readiness.  The  capacity  of  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF)  (the  Executing  Agency)  and  the  National  Agriculture  Forestry 
Extension  Service  (NAFES)  (the  Implementing  Agency)  has  improved  over  the  course  of  the 
current project implementation. Additional financing is considered to be a suitable instrument to 
promptly  respond  to  the  government’s  needs  and  sustain  the  development  momentum  of  the 
current  project.  Therefore,  the  overall  project  will  enhance  the  positive  impacts  of  sustainable 
smallholder commercial agriculture and improve livelihoods through PPPs for agribusiness. The 
establishment  of  PPPs  will  enhance  and  sustain  agriculture  production  techniques  and 
marketing in the project areas. 

10. 
Sustainable agricultural practices promoted by the Project will generate climate change 
benefits  by  building  more  climate  resilient  agrisystems  and  reducing  agricultural  greenhouse 
gas emissions. Management practices and approaches to organic farming will optimize use of 
(i)  bio-pesticides  and  minimum  tillage  systems;  (ii)  natural,  locally  available  nutrients,  mostly 
from  manure,  crop  residues,  and  weed  biomass;  and  (iii)  nitrogen-fixing  legumes  grown  in 
rotation.  The  interventions  will  promote  carbon  sequestration  and  soil  stabilization  through 
increased storage of carbon in soil and plant biomass. 

11.  While the current project was classified in the some gender benefit category, the active 
participation  of  women  was  evident  during  its  implementation.  It  involved  women  in  various 
capacity  development  activities  such  as  entrepreneurial  and  group  management  training, 
agribusiness  workshops,  and  strategic  community  dialogue.  Women  took  the  lead  in  organic 
vegetable farming, corn production, food processing, and rice miller groups. The participation of 
women  in  study  tours  and  farmer  exchanges  has  demonstrated  that  entrepreneurship  and 
marketing  skills  of  women  have  improved.  Women  took  the  initiative  in  preparing  strategic 
production and marketing plans in farmer groups. This momentum needs to be continued and 
strengthened.  The  overall  project  will  give  priority  to  women  beneficiaries  in  implementing  the 
planned activities, and encourage more women to participate in project implementation, benefit 
monitoring, dissemination of project achievements, and evaluation of project performance.

C. 

Outputs 

13. 
The project design considered lessons learned from the current project, particularly with 
regard  to  the  replication  of  integrated  agribusiness  models,  expansion  of  organic  farming  and 
post-harvesting  practices,  and  strengthening  of  the  capacity  of  farmer  groups  in  production 
techniques. The Project will have five outputs. 

14. 
Output  1:  Strengthened  farmer  production  and  marketing  groups.  Activities  will 
include  (i)  capacity  building  of  FPMGs  through  training  in  extension  services,  management  of 
farmer  groups,  new  agricultural  production  techniques,  post-harvest  practices,  and  marketing; 
(ii)  promoting  commodity  markets  to  improve  the  environment  and  social  performance  of 
agriculture  and  value-added  agricultural  products;  (iii)  continuing  support  for  96  FPMGs  in 
existing  districts;  (iv)  establishing  28  new  FPMGs  in  new  districts;  (v)  establishing  revolving 
funds  for  FPMGs  in  new  districts;  (vi)  overseas  and  in-country  training  on  rice  planting 
technologies  and  livestock  rearing;  and  (vii)  supporting  organic  farming  groups  involved  in 
certified organic agriculture products. 

15. 
Output 2: Replicated post-harvest technology and practices. Activities will include (i) 
promoting value addition to agricultural products through post-harvest technology and practices; 
(ii)  supplying  post-harvest  equipment  and  training  to  FPMGs  on  their  operation  and 
maintenance; and (iii) organizing exchange visits and study tours to stimulate new agricultural 
initiatives and post-harvest practices. 

16. 
Output 3: Strengthened extension services of the Agriculture Technical Extension 
Center. Activities will include (i) strengthening PPPs for agricultural research and development 
through integrated extension practices on improved rice quality and productivity by involving the 
rice  research  centers,  agriculture  technical  extension  center  (ATEC),  FPMGs,  and  rice  miller 
groups;11 (ii)  strengthening  ATEC’s  staff  capacity  to  increase the  efficiency  of  their  operations; 
(iii) establishing rice seed storage facilities for ATEC; (iv) procuring post-harvest equipment, rice 
transplanting  machinery,  and  laboratory  equipment  for  quality  tests;  (v)  upgrading  training 
facilities  in  the  Lao-China  Agriculture  Research  Center  in  Champassak  province;  and  (vi) 
mobilizing  post-graduate  students  to  facilitate  FPMG  adoption  of  improved  rice  planting  and 
harvesting processes. 

17. 
Output  4:  Improved  farmer  production  and  marketing  groups’  knowledge  of 
agribusiness  practices.  Activities  will  include  (i)  facilitating  inter-sectoral  information-sharing 
on  agribusiness  practices  through  trade  forums  and  consultation  meetings;  (ii)  promoting 
cooperation  among  farmers,  village  extension  workers,  FPMGs,  and  trade  groups  to  identify 
market needs and ensure the quality of agricultural products; (iii) adopting best practices for the 
trade  and  promotion  of  agricultural  products  and  services;  (iv)  strengthening  the  agribusiness

D. 

Investment and Financing Plans 

20. 
The project is estimated to cost $5.50 million (Table 1). As of July 2011, the cost of the 
current  project  was  $15.23  million  equivalent,  financed  by  an  ADF  loan  of  $12.00  million 
equivalent (denominated in SDR). The overall project is estimated to cost $20.73 million. 

21. 
The government has requested a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR3,155,000 
($5.0 million equivalent) from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the Project. The 
loan will have a 32-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per 
annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum  thereafter,  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as set forth in the draft loan agreement. The loan will be used for civil works, vehicles 
and  equipment,  training  and  workshops,  consulting  services,  incremental  operating  costs, 
interest  during  implementation,  contingencies,  and  taxes  and  duties.  The  government  has 
requested ADB to (i) consider approval of advance contracting for civil works13 and goods; and 
(ii)  retroactive  financing  of  about  $500,000  for  consulting  services,  civil  works,  and  goods 
contract packages.

The  implementation  arrangements  are  described  in  detail  in  the  project  administration

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

24. 
Project impact can be expected to be similar to that of the current project. Selection of 
the  targeted  villages  was  carried  out  through  various  consultation  meetings  and  government 
procedures  in  the  field  and  follows  provincial  and  district  development  strategies.  Economic 
benefits, financial viability, and project sustainability were analyzed based on the demonstrated 
performance of the current project. 

A. 

Technical 

25. 
A  national  project  steering  committee,  chaired  by  the  vice  minister  of  MAF,  has 
functioned well to provide oversight on implementation and coordination. ONPD has effectively 
coordinated with relevant agencies involved in the project implementation. The implementation 
arrangements  at  central,  provincial,  and  district  levels,  established  under  the  current  project, 
have  proved  to  be  effective.  These  existing  structures  will  provide  a  platform  for  the  smooth 
implementation  of  the  Project  and  provide  the  opportunity  for  active  participation  by  farmers. 
Post-harvest techniques, extension services, and new agricultural initiatives of organic farming 
provided by the current project have demonstrated their relevance with farmers benefiting from 
higher  incomes  and  improved  livelihoods.  The  agribusiness  models  established  under  the 
current  project  have  been  effective  and  were  important  in  supporting  commercialization  of 
agriculture under the framework of the Lao PDR agriculture sector strategy and master plan. 

                                                 
14 ADB  and  the  government  agreed  on  counterpart  funding  in-kind  during  the  CPS  consultations  since  the 

government faces challenges in providing cash contributions. 

 

 7 

B. 

Economic and Financial 

26. 
The  economic  benefits  of  the  Project  will  include  (i)  improved  agricultural  productivity 
amongst  direct  farmer  group  beneficiaries  and  those  who  can  benefit  indirectly  from  project 
activities, (ii) improved household incomes amongst participating farmers, (iii) an expanded area 
of  influence  for  project  interventions,  (vi)  more  diversified  farming  household  income  sources 
through  the introduction of  higher  valued  commodities,  (v)  improved  input  supply  mechanisms 
through group initiatives for credit, equipment, animal health products, fertilizer, and agricultural 
machinery,  (vi)  enhanced  technical  and  communication  capacities  amongst  extension  staff 
within  MAF,  (vii)  strengthened  PPPs  for  agribusiness,  and  (viii)  improved  technical  and 
management  capacities  amongst  target  rural  communities.  The  economic  analysis  of  the 
additional  financing  indicates  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  22.4%  based  on 
quantified  incremental  benefits  from  increased  productivity  in  wet  and  dry  season  rice,  maize, 
vegetables and from livestock production. While the reassessment of the current project shows 
an  EIRR  of  16.3%,15 the  combined  impact  is  to  elevate  the  EIRR  to  an  estimated  16.9%.  The 
investment  is  sensitive  to  price  decreases  in  rice  but  this  risk  is  considered  minimal  as 
conservative  estimates  were  used  in  the  analysis.  Overall  the  Project  is  considered  a  sound 
investment contributing to economic growth of the area, to farmer household incomes that will 
further reduce poverty as benefits are broadly distributed.16 

C. 

Governance 

27. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  in  relation  to  project  activities.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the project administration manual (footnote 12). The 
Project  will  assist  provincial  and  district  administrations  in  addressing  governance  issues.  The 
involvement  of  communities  and  extension  workers  in  project  implementation  is  expected  to 
increase the transparency of project-related decision-making and accountability. 

D. 

Poverty and Social 

28. 
The  Project  is  located  in  provinces  and  districts  primarily  contiguous  to  the  Mekong 
River. Thus, most of these districts are not among the poorest in the Lao PDR. However, of the 
16 districts where the project has been implemented since 2002, two in Champassak are rated 
among the 45 poorest districts nationally. Of the eight new districts, Phalanxay in Savannakhet 
is  rated  as  among  the  poorest  with  over  11%  poor  households.  Of  the  64,400  households  in 
new districts, 1,830 are considered poor. Of the total, 3,930 households belong to various ethnic 
groups, and 270 are households headed by women. The overall project will enable households 
to  benefit  from  increased  trade  and  economic  growth  through  effective  agricultural  extension 
and marketing efforts. The eight new districts have villages with the same ethnic heterogeneity 
as in the current project. Villages are not remote and have a long history of cross-cultural and 
economic  interaction  with  other  groups.  They  are  all  involved,  at  different  levels,  in  some 
commercial  activities.  The  Project  has  been  screened  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009). As project processes are highly participatory, involvement in activities 
is based on the household’s willingness to participate. 

29. 
The main gender issues in smallholder development are low productivity among women 
producers;  limited  knowledge,  credit,  and  skills  to  engage  in  alternative  income-generating

 8 

activities such as agribusinesses, resulting in risk adverse attitudes; limited access to extension 
services;  limited  knowledge  of  marketing;  and  limited  participation  in  FPMGs.  An  important 
lesson learned from the current project is the need for explicit attention to gender equality such 
as  setting  targets  for  women’s  participation.  The  overall  project  will  address  this  issue  by 
introducing  gender-inclusive  design  features  and  targets,  which  are  reflected  in  the  gender 
action  plan. 17  The  implementation  of  the  gender  action  plan  will  be  monitored  by  ONPD, 
assisted by a national gender and development specialist. 

E. 

Safeguards 

30. 
Environmental  safeguards  (category  B).  None  of  the  proposed  activities  directly 
impinges upon the environment. The Project will have limited environmental impact and, in all 
such  cases,  effective  mitigation  measures  can  be  designed.  Promotion  of  sustainable  farming 
and  associated  marketing  activities  will  have  beneficial  environmental  impacts.  Village  post-
harvest  operations  are  small-scale  and  will  therefore  have  no  negative  environmental  impact. 
Awareness-raising  activities  will  increase  community  consciousness  of  the  need  to  follow 
sustainable  practices.  In  addition,  no  new  construction  of  major  facilities  or  physical 
infrastructure  is  planned.  Following  the  procedures  set  forth  in  the  environmental  assessment 
and  review  framework,  a  screening  process  will  be  established  to  categorize  subproject 
activities  according

site-specific  issues  consistent  with  government  requirements  and  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement  (2009).  An  environmental  safeguard  specialist  will  assist  project  staff  in  complying 
with the requirements and monitor these procedures.

31. 
Involuntary resettlement (category C). The Project has been screened for involuntary 
resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  safeguards  against  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009).  Project  activities  will  not  involve  any  involuntary  acquisition  of  land  or  assets,  and  no 
compensation will be required. None of the project components, activities, or community works 
(e.g.,  construction  of  community  rice  drying  facilities,  training  rooms,  and  rice  storage)  is 
expected to entail any land acquisition, conversion, donation, or restrictions of access that will 
trigger ADB's Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009). 

32. 
Indigenous peoples (category C). The purpose of the Project remains the promotion of 
commercial  smallholder  agriculture  and  associated  agribusiness  in  the  Lao  PDR,  with  the 
overall objectives of achieving sustained increases in rural incomes and long-term reductions in 
rural poverty through growth of the commercial agriculture sector. Guiding principles of village 
selection  to  achieve  this  aim  remain  the  same,  namely  in  areas  with  high  potential  for 
agribusiness and where farmers are already linked to external markets. The Project is not being 
carried  out  in  remote  upland  areas  characterized  by  higher  numbers  of  poorer  ethnic  groups. 
Households from different ethnic groups in the overall project area have largely assimilated into 
a  settled  agricultural  production  economy,  and  there  continues  to  be  no  significant  difference 
between ethnic groups, their needs, demands, social functioning, and development objectives. 
Household participation in the Project is based on individual willingness or interest determined 
through  a  community  consultation  process.  Safeguards  screening  against  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  (2009)  indicates  that  no  adverse  effects  on  different  ethnic  groups  are 
anticipated  and  no  commercial  development  of  cultural  or  natural  resources  is  involved.

 9 

Opportunities  under  the  overall  project  for  developing  commercial  agriculture  are  directed 
towards households from all different ethnic groups that seek to take advantage of smallholder 
engagement in commercial agricultural production. 

F. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

33. 
The  overall  project  is  categorized  as  “low  risk”  as  (i)  the  loan  amount  is  $5  million; 
(ii) post-harvest  technologies  have  been  tested  and  proven  to  be  technically  viable;  (iii)  MAF 
and NAFES have gained the necessary experience and skills to implement the overall project; 
and (iv) the safeguard categorization is other than A. A risk assessment and risk management 
plan  was  prepared. 18 Major  risks  and  mitigating  measures  are  summarized  in  Table  3  and 
described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITION 

34. 
The  government  has  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  overall  project  shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan agreement. 

The government and MAF have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the Project, 

35. 
which are set forth in the loan agreement. 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

36. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  in  various 
currencies  equivalent  to  SDR  3,155,000  to  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  for  the 
additional  financing  of  the  Smallholder  Development  Project,  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 
1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32-years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such 
other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft 
loan agreement presented to the Board.
